jyoshu

The terrorist attack in London recently is a very real tragedy. 
 
 A lot of people I've talked to and some of media are wondering if England and other parts of Europe will now see that terrorism is something to taken seriously and that they should be supporting the U.S. more in the war on terrorism. 
 
 Personally, I don't think it will make a lot of difference, and they won't follow the U.S. lead to truly fight it. I hope they don't follow Spain's lead and basically withdraw troops which is what the terrorists want.

post_info.post_title: Will the London Attack be a Wakeup call for England?

Big_Bear_Scot

The terrorist attack in London recently is a very real tragedy.
 
 A lot of people I've talked to and some of media are wondering if England and other parts of Europe will now see that terrorism is something to taken seriously and that they should be supporting the U.S. more in the war on terrorism.
 
 Personally, I don't think it will make a lot of difference, and they won't follow the U.S. lead to truly fight it. I hope they don't follow Spain's lead and basically withdraw troops which is what the terrorists want..

 
 Is that what the terrorists want ?
 
 We are still unsure who carried out the attacks and what they want. I think their goal was just to kill people and cause the maximum amount of disruption to London.
 
 Can I ask how can the UK do more in the War on Terror ? Isn't the UK the staunchest ally of the US in the War on Terrorism ?
jyoshu

Can I ask how can the UK do more in the War on Terror ? Isn't the UK the staunchest ally of the US in the War on Terrorism ?

 
 Tony Blair is, but from what I know a lot of the people there don't really support it. Correct me if I'm wrong.
 
 I think a lot of the problem is just that Europe (not just UK) views Bush's as a warring president, and they think of that as somehow "cowboyish." But Bush's war on terrorism is justified.
Clive14

The terrorist attack in London recently is a very real tragedy. 
True.
 
 
A lot of people I've talked to and some of media are wondering if England and other parts of Europe will now see that terrorism is something to taken seriously and that they should be supporting the U.S. more in the war on terrorism. 
That is because "a lot of people I've talked to and some of media" are rather ignorant of the world and think it begins and ends with the USA. Britain has been fighting terrorism for decades. We do not need "wake up calls" to tell us it needs fighting. We also (hopefully) will not run around like headless chickens bombing the planet at random in retaliation. We certainly should continue to tackle terrorism, but joining Bush's mad crusade is not the way to do it.
 
 
Personally, I don't think it will make a lot of difference, and they won't follow the U.S. lead to truly fight it. I hope they don't follow Spain's lead and basically withdraw troops which is what the terrorists want.
You seem rather knowledgable on these terrorists to know their motives. Assuming they were an "Islamic" group, I find it difficult to understand what their motives could be as they targeted an area of London with one of the largest Muslim populations.
Big_Bear_Scot

Tony Blair is, but from what I know a lot of the people there don't really support it. Correct me if I'm wrong.
 
 I think a lot of the problem is just that Europe (not just UK) views Bush's as a warring president, and they think of that as somehow "cowboyish." But Bush's war on terrorism is justified.
 
 
 We and the World collectively supported the US when they invaded Afghanistan, Intelligence Agencies across the World share information about Terrorist Organisation and Law Enforcements Agencies around the World cooperate in the capture and disruption of Terrorist Cells. 
 
 So I really don't know what you are getting at, could you please explain your position to me ?

as they targeted an area of London with one of the largest Muslim populations.

A lot of people I've talked to and some of media are wondering if England and other parts of Europe will now see that terrorism is something to taken seriously and that they should be supporting the U.S. more in the war on terrorism. 

 People take terrorism seriously, we've had it for decades, it's not something new. However, most don't think attacking other countries is the right way to combat terrorism. The "War on terror" is utterly ridiculous. You can't win it, you can't lose it, it's just some silly name that has no real meaning.
 
 
I hope they don't follow Spain's lead and basically withdraw troops which is what the terrorists want.

At least in Britain, there is a fair bit of support for the war (around 50% iirc), whereas in Spain, it was a lot more unpopular. Either way, it's unlikely that Britain will withdraw from Iraq. It wouldn't really solve anything. Even though I was against the war, now we're in it, we've got to stick it through.

Good point. The motives of these "Islamic" terrorists are difficult to understand (to put it mildly).

 
 The motives are simple and clear. You should just do a simple search on the web and you will find plenty of information about what they want.

 2. All non-muslims are the enemy of the truth and want to infect us with their illness.

Didn't they also target the country who has given billions of dollars in aid to Muslim populations across the world? Not to mention defended Muslim people against perceived genocide.

 
 
I find it difficult to understand what their motives could be as they targeted an area of London with one of the largest Muslim populations.

 
 Everytime the Islamic extremists blow themselves up in a marketplace in an Arab country, they often kill other Muslims. So I don't see why this should be a surprise.
 
 No offense, but it's this very lack of realization about what Islamic extremism is capable of doing that tells me some people in Europe just still don't get it.
 
 
People take terrorism seriously, we've had it for decades, it's not something new. However, most don't think attacking other countries is the right way to combat terrorism. The "War on terror" is utterly ridiculous. You can't win it, you can't lose it, it's just some silly name that has no real meaning. 

 
 The alternative is no action. "The War of Terror" is simply active work combatting terrorism, in a pre-emptive way. In fact much of it is intelligence and investigative work, and diplomacy. The military part of it just happens to be the most visible because that's all the media spoonfeeds people.

The alternative is no action. "The War of Terror" is simply active work combatting terrorism, in a pre-emptive way. In fact much of it is intelligence and investigative work, and diplomacy. The military part of it just happens to be the most visible because that's all the media spoonfeeds people.

No offense, but it's this very lack of realization about what Islamic extremism is capable of doing that tells me some people in Europe just still don't get

 
 Europe as a whole has been dealing with terrorism for decades, Terrorism just didn't start when the Two Towers fell. For example France has dealt with Algerian Islamic Extermists in the 80s and the 90s http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,176139,00.html
Becca

A lot of people I've talked to and some of media are wondering if England and other parts of Europe will now see that terrorism is something to taken seriously and that they should be supporting the U.S. more in the war on terrorism.
 
 Very few people are disputing that terrorism is something to be taken seriously. Remember, terrorism did not start with Al-Quaida. England has plenty of experience of Irish terrorism. However, some of the English people (myself included) do not feel that the way the war in Iraq was carried out was the best way to attempt to combat terrorism. Frankly, breaking this down into "you are either totally with us or totally against us" is distinctly unhelpful.
